___ man with h/o crohns s/p total colectomy with

and chronic dehydration.  He has a living donor (cousin's 
___ appropriate crossmatches and serologies were performed 
and were suitable.  He presented for translant. 
 
Past Medical History:
PMHx PSHx: ESRD ___ interstitial nephritis ___ Asacol on HD via 
RIJ tunnel cath ___.  
- Crohn's disease s/p total colectomy with ileoanal pullthrough 
___ years ago at ___

Pertinent Results:
___ 06:45PM BLOOD WBC-8.5 RBC-3.44* Hgb-10.9* Hct-32.3* 
MCV-94 MCH-31.5 MCHC-33.6 RDW-13.0 Plt ___
___ 06:45PM BLOOD Glucose-126* UreaN-27* Creat-4.1* Na-143

___ 01:10PM BLOOD Glucose-110* UreaN-36* Creat-3.7* Na-139 
K-5.1 Cl-109* HCO3-20* AnGap-15
 
Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, he underwent living donor renal transplant with 6 
___ double J ureteral stent. Of note the venous anastomosis 
was redone intra op. The kidney was making urine. Surgeon was 
Dr. ___. Please refer to operative note further details. 
He received induction immunosuppression which consisted of ATG, 
Cellcept and Solu-Medrol. Prograf was started. 

Postop overnight, urine output decreased to 35 and SBP was in 
low ___. Normal saline boluses were given without much change. 
5% albumin was then given with gradual increase in urine output 
and SBP to low 100s. He received a 2nd dose of ATG. Prograf was 
held as this was suspected of decreasing urine output. Incision 
was intact with scant serosanguinous drainage. Abdomen was 
non-distended. He experienced a little bit of nausea and was 
given Zofran. Urine output gradually increased to 150ml/hr. He 
continued to receive ___ NS cc/cc urine output replacements. 

On postop day 2, urine output continued to average 210 to 100 
cc. IV fluid replacements were decreased to a maintenance rate D 
___ at 100cc. Vital signs were stable. A 3rd dose of ATG 
(125mg each dose) was administered and Prograf was started at 
2mg bid.  Diet was advanced to regular, however, the patient was 
reluctant to advance given h/o Crohn's and anticipation of 
multiple BMs with regular food. By postop day 5, he was taking 
solid food but c/o multiple loose stools. Imodium 2mg daily was 
started with decrease in stool output. On postop day 6, urine 
output was ~ 2 liter per day. Creatinine was down to 1.9. 
Incision was intact and without drainage. He was taking 
Oxycodone for pain with good relief and was ambulating 
independently. Medication teaching went well. Dapsone was 
started ___ PCP prophylaxis given sulfa allergy 
precluding Bactrim. G6PD was 11.8. 

Of note, Prograf level increased to a high of 18.4 on ___. ___ 
dose of Prograf was held and prograf 3mg was given in am ___. 
Trough level was 7.0 that day and dose was increased to 4mg bid. 
He was instructed to have trough level drawn at ___ Lab 
on ___ and ___. Cellcept was well tolerated. Steroids were 
tapered off. 

He was discharged to home in stable condition. 

 
Medications on Admission:
lisinopril 2.5mg', nephrocaps

Disp #*50 Tablet Refills:*0

Home

esrd 
crohn's 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call the Transplant office ___ if you have any 
of the following: temperature of 101 or greater, chills, nausea, 
vomiting, inability take any of your medications, increased 
abdominal pain, incision redness/bleeding/drainage, decreased 
urine output, weight gain of 3 pounds in a day, edema or any 
concerns
-you will need to have labs drawn tomorrow, ___ then 
___ then twice weekly on ___ and ___
-you may shower with soap and water, rinse and pat incision dry. 
do not scrub incision. Do not apply powder/lotion or ointment to 
incision
-do not lift anything heavier than 10 pounds. no straining

___
 

Output:
target:
||startoftext||The patient is a 51-year-old male who underwent a living non-related renal transplant due to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) caused by medication toxicity and chronic dehydration. He has a history of Crohn's disease, which was treated with total colectomy and ileoanal pullthrough 20 years ago. He has been on hemodialysis since then. The patient has allergies to sulfa, penicillins, and Asacol. His past medical history includes ESRD, interstitial nephritis, and Asacol on HD via RIJ tunnel cath. 

During his hospital stay, the patient received induction immunosuppression and underwent a successful transplant with a living donor. He experienced some complications, including decreased urine output and low blood pressure, which were managed with fluid replacement and medication adjustments. The patient was discharged with a stable condition and was instructed to follow up with the transplant office and to have regular lab tests. His medications at discharge included acetaminophen, dapsone, famotidine, mycophenolate mofetil, nystatin, amlodipine, oxycodone, tacrolimus, and valganciclovir. ||endoftext||

age: 64. gender: F.  
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___

Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins / Ibuprofen
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
inferior STEMI
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
cardiac catheterization with ___ placed to RCA - ___

 
History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ year-old female with a PMH of HTN, 
hyperlipidemia, hyperglycemia, fibromyalgia who presents s/p 
cath for inferior STEMI. She describes CP starting at 11pm last 
night while she was watching TV. She described fairly sudden 
onset ___ chest tightness and pressure in the chest radiating 
down the left arm and to the back. She denied any preceding 
exertion or other precipitating events. She denied associated 
palpitations, shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, 
diaphoresis, or HA/ light-headedness. She tried SL NTG x 1 
without relief of pain. She complained of "heartburn" preceding 
the event as well as intermittently within the past 1 week, 
which she does not usually get. She c/o baseline chest and torso 
pain due to fibromyalgia. 
.
In the ED initially, VS: T 97.0 HR 84  BP 127/79  RR 16 O2 
98%RA. Her initial EKG showed TWI in the inferior leads with CE 
neg. x 1. Recheck EKG later due to c/o recurrence of CP showed 
2mm STE in the inferior leads and STD in I and aVL. A code STEMI 
was called and she was take to the cath lab. She received ASA, 
morphine 2mg IV, lopressor 5mg IV x 2, heparin bolus, plavix, 
and integrallin gtt. 
.
In the cath lab, she had an 80% stenosis at the bifurcation of 
the LAD and OM which was too difficult to ___ for concern for 
jailing the artery. In addition it was not in the distribution 
of her STE. She also had a 90% lesion to the mid RCA which was 
stented with a DES. LCX showed minimal disease. She had IVIS 
prior to stenting.
.
Currently, she feels well without complaints. She denies CP, 
SOB, palpitations, HA/ dizziness, pain or numbness/ weakness/ 
paresthesias in the extremities new or different from baseline.
.  
Of note, the patient had a negative stress MIBI in ___ with EF 
71%.
.
On review of systems, she denies any prior history of stroke, 
TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the 
time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black 
stools or red stools. He denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. 
She denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other 
review of systems were negative.  
Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of chest pain, 
dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, 
ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope. 

 
Past Medical History:
hyperlipidemia
hypertesnion
hyperglycemia/borderline diabetes
fibromyalgia
spinal stenosis
chronic pain syndrome
depression
bilateral cataracts s/p surgery, L surgery complicated by visual 
loss
hx of labrynthitis

___
Family History:
There is a family history of premature coronary artery disease 
in the patient's father - died of MI at age ___. Mother died at 
___ of uterine cancer. No other personal or family history of DM, 
CAD, ca to patient's knowledge.

 
Physical Exam:

HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRLA, EOMI. Conjunctiva were

Chest: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp

assess posterior exam due to reclined position), no crackles,

Abd: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. 
Ext: No c/c/e. No femoral bruits. R groin site without hematoma 
or bruit.
Skin: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas.  
.

Right: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+  
Left: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+  
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 03:00AM   WBC-5.3 RBC-4.18* HGB-13.0 HCT-36.5 MCV-87 
MCH-31.1 MCHC-35.6* RDW-13.5  PLT COUNT-208
___ 03:00AM   ___ PTT-31.8 ___

POTASSIUM-3.6 CHLORIDE-94* TOTAL CO2-27 ANION GAP-13

___ 02:49PM   CHOLEST-117
___ 02:49PM   TRIGLYCER-54 HDL CHOL-48 CHOL/HDL-2.4 
LDL(CALC)-58
___ 04:15PM   %HbA1c-5.4

___ 05:55AM BLOOD Glucose-110* UreaN-5* Creat-0.5 Na-138 
K-3.8 Cl-103 HCO3-28 AnGap-11
.
Admission EKG NSR, nml axis/ intervals, poor RWP, and TWI in III 
and avF new since prior in ___.
Pre-cath EKG (with CP) showed 2mm STE in II, III, and avF and 
STD in I and aVL.    
Post-cath EKG demonstrated NSR, normalization of STE in II, III, 
and avF with TWI in III and TWF in F. Resolved STD in I and L. 
.
___ CARDIAC CATHETERIZATION:
COMMENTS:      
1. Coronary angiography in this right dominant system revealed 
two 
vessel coronary artery disease. The LMCA had minimal disease 
with modest 
calcification. The LAD had moderate-severe diffuse disease in 
the 
mid-segment. There were serial 80% lesions in the LAD at the 
bifurcation 
with the D1. The D1 was a large bifurcating vessel with a 
proximal 80% 
lesion. There were left-right collaterals noted. The LCx was a 
non-dominant vessel without critical lesions. The RCA was a 
dominant 
vessel with origin 20% calcified lesion and mid-segment 90% 
lesion. There was mild distal RCA disease. 
2. There was normal systemic arterial pressure with SBP 120 mmHg 
and DBP 
64 bpm. 
3. Successful stenting of the mid-RCA with 3.0 X 28 mm Cypher 
___ 
___ to 3.25 mm with no residual stenosis (see PTCA 
comments for 
detail). 
4. No demonstrable critical ostial RCA disease as documented by 
MLD on 
IVUS. 
.
FINAL DIAGNOSIS:     
1. Two vessel coronary artery disease. 
2. Successful stenting of the mid RCA with Cypher DES. 
.
___ Echo: The left atrium is normal in size. Left 
ventricular wall thickness, cavity size and regional/global 
systolic function are normal (LVEF 70%) There is no ventricular 
septal defect. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall 
motion are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly 
thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. Trace aortic 
regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly 
thickened. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Trivial mitral 
regurgitation is seen. The left ventricular inflow pattern 
suggests impaired relaxation. There is mild pulmonary artery 
systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. There 
is an anterior space which most likely represents a fat pad. 

Compared with the findings of the prior study (images reviewed) 
of ___, the aortic regurgitation is reduced; other 
findings are similar.  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient is a ___ year-old female with a PMH of HTN, 
hyperlipidemia, hyperglycemia, fibromyalgia who presents with an 
inferior STEMI. 
.  
#. CAD: The patient presented with chest pain and was found to 
have an inferior STEMI on EKG. The patient was taken emergently 
for cardiac catheterization on ___, during which time a ___ 
___ was placed in the RCA to a mid-segment 90% lesion. 
Moderately severe diffuse disease was noted in the mid-segment 
of the LAD and at the bifurcation of D1;this was poorly suitable 
for PCI because of the very diffuse and bifurcation disease. The 
patient tolerated cardiac cath very well, with no recurrence of 
chest pain during her hospital course. Peak CK was in the 170s, 
EKG changes were resolving post-cath. ___ Echo showed no 
evidence of systolic dysfunction or WMA. The patient was 
monitored on telemetry with no significant events. She was 
continued on pravastatin 80mg daily, ASA 325mg, and a BB. Plavix 
was started for duration of at least 12months. ACEI was not 
added given that there was no evidence of any systolic 
dysfunction on echo. The patient was advised that she would need 
additional stress testing in ___ weeks to further evaluate 
cardiac status. Given diffuse disease, she may be a candidate 
for CABG in the future.
.
#. Pump: The patient had mild diastolic dysfunction on ___ echo 
in setting of post-MI. There was no systolic dysfunction or wall 
motion abnormality seen on echo. She was discharged on decreased 
dose of lasix (20mg daily), which was initially started for 
history ___ swelling by her PCP. 
.  
#. Rhythm: The patient was in NSR with no acute issues. She was 
continued on metoprolol while inhouse, and was discharged on 
home dose of atenolol upon discharge.
.  
#. Borderline diabetes: The patient had HbA1c of 5.8% with good 
glycemic control with diet-modification. 
.
#. Chronic pain/fibromyalgia: The patient was continued on 
dilaudid prn.
.  
#. RLE pain: The patient was continued on home dose of 
neurontin.
.
#. The patient was discharged on ___ in good condition, VSS, 
ambulating well, CP-free. She was advised to follow-up with her 
cardiologist and PCP shortly after discharge.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted with a heart attack (STEMI) for which you were 
taken for cardiac catheterization. Catheterization showed 
several blockages in the heart, one of which (Right Coronary 
Artery) was thought to be causing your heart attack. A drug 
eluting ___ was placed in this artery. You should continue to 
take aspirin for life and plavix for 12 months without skipping 
any doses to prevent clot formation in the ___. Do NOT stop 
plavix for any reason without speaking to your cardiologist 
first. You may need an additional stress test in ___ weeks to 
evaluate your heart function. 
.
You should continue to take all your medications as prescribed. 
You should attend all of your follow-up appointments. (Note: 
your lasix was decreased - please discuss dosing with your PCP 
or cardiologist.)
.
If you experience any chest pain, shortness of breath, 
palpitations, dizziness, or any other symptoms that are 
concerning to you, you should call your PCP or go to the ER for 
further evaluation.

target:
||startoftext||The patient is a 64-year-old female who presented with an inferior STEMI. She has a past medical history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, hyperglycemia, fibromyalgia, spinal stenosis, chronic pain syndrome, depression, and bilateral cataracts. She has a family history of premature coronary artery disease in her father, who died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 55. 

The patient's allergies include penicillins and ibuprofen. She was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of chest pain and was found to have an 80% stenosis at the bifurcation of the LAD and OM, which was too difficult to stent due to concern for jailing the artery. She also had a 90% lesion to the mid RCA, which was stented with a DES. 

The patient's medications at discharge include ASA, morphine, lopressor, heparin, plavix, and integrallin. Her physical examination was normal, with no signs of chest pain, shortness of breath, or palpitations. Her laboratory results showed normal white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count, with elevated troponin and creatine kinase levels. 

The patient's diagnosis is two-vessel coronary artery disease, with successful stenting of the mid-RCA with a Cypher DES. Her echocardiogram showed normal left atrial size, left ventricular wall thickness, and regional/global systolic function, with mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. ||endoftext||

age: 55. gender: M.  
Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___

Latex
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
rapidly progressive syndrome of
back and radiating leg pain with progressive lower extremity
weakness, and the progressive loss of the ability to walk
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Lumbar posterior decompression

 
History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ generally healthy
male who presented with a rapidly progressive syndrome of
back and radiating leg pain with progressive lower extremity
weakness, and the progressive loss of the ability to walk.
Due to the severity of symptoms, the progressive nature of
his neurological deficit, the severity of his stenosis, and
the natural history of this disorder, he elected to undergo
surgical treatment.
 
Past Medical History:
see H+P
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
see H+P
 
Physical Exam:
see H+P
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the ___ Spine Surgery Service and 
taken to the Operating Room for the above procedure.  Refer to 
the dictated operative note for further details.  The surgery 
was without complication and the patient was transferred to the 
PACU in a stable condition.  TEDs/pnemoboots were used for 
postoperative DVT prophylaxis.  Intravenous antibiotics were 
continued for 24hrs postop per standard protocol. Initial postop 
pain was controlled with a PCA.  Diet was advanced as tolerated. 
 The patient was transitioned to oral pain medication when 
tolerating PO diet.  Foley was removed on POD#2.  Physical 
therapy was consulted for mobilization OOB to ambulate.  
Hospital course was otherwise unremarkable.  On the day of 
discharge the patient was afebrile with stable vital signs, 
comfortable on oral pain control and tolerating a regular diet. 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed for pain.  
2. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).  
3. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 hours) 
as needed for pain.
Disp:*75 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO 
DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*90 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
5. finasteride 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
6. tamsulosin 0.4 mg Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr PO HS (at bedtime).
Disp:*60 Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr(s)* Refills:*2*
7. omeprazole 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*60 Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.)(s)* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service

___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
back and
radiating leg pain, in the setting of progressive lower 
extremity
weakness, and the progressive loss of ability to walk.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You have undergone the following operation: Lumbar Decompression 
Without Fusion

Immediately after the operation:

-Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 
2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand 
more than ~45 minutes without moving around.

-Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy: 
o2-3 times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as 
part of your recovery.  You can walk as much as you can 
tolerate. 
oLimit any kind of lifting.

-Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet. You may have some 
constipation after surgery.  You have been given medication to 
help with this issue.

-Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days.  If the incision is 
draining cover it with a new sterile dressing.  If it is dry 
then you can leave the incision open to the air.  Once the 
incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the 
operation) you may take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a 
bath or pool.  If the incision starts draining at anytime after 
surgery, do not get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile 
dressing and call the office. 

-You should resume taking your normal home medications.

-You have also been given Additional Medications to control 
your pain. Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so please plan ahead.  You can either have them 
mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on 
___ 2.  We are not allowed to call in or fax narcotic 
prescriptions (oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to your pharmacy. 
 In addition, we are only allowed to write for pain medications 
for 90 days from the date of surgery.

Physical Therapy:
Ambulate as tolerated. 
Treatments Frequency:
Keep dressing clean and dry
 
Followup Instructions:
___
 

Output:
target: ||startoftext||The patient is a 55-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with a rapidly progressive syndrome of back and radiating leg pain, progressive lower extremity weakness, and the progressive loss of the ability to walk. He underwent a lumbar posterior decompression procedure without complication. The patient has a history of allergies to Ibuprofen, Penicillins, Sulfa, and Latex. His past medical history is significant for spinal stenosis, and he has a family history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and obstructive sleep apnea. The patient was prescribed several medications at discharge, including acetaminophen, docusate sodium, oxycodone, hydrochlorothiazide, finasteride, and tamsulosin. He was advised to follow a normal diet, avoid lifting heavy objects, and to ambulate as tolerated. The patient was discharged home with instructions to follow up with his doctor and to take his medications as directed. ||endoftext||

||startoftext||The patient is an 81-year-old male who presented with a syncopal episode after a baseball game. He has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) with recent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), chronic heart failure (CHF), end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis, hypertension (HTN), and atrial fibrillation (Afib). He was admitted to the hospital for further evaluation and treatment.

Upon admission, the patient's vital signs were notable for a temperature of 97.2°F, heart rate of 52 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 151/48 mmHg. His physical examination revealed a bradycardic rhythm, normal rhythm, and a III/VI holosystolic murmur heard throughout the precordium.

Laboratory results showed elevated levels of troponin (0.53 ng/mL) and creatinine (11.0 mg/dL), as well as mild anemia (Hgb 11.3 g/dL). Imaging studies revealed severe aortic stenosis with a valve area of 1.0 cm² or less, as well as mild degenerative changes in the ankle joints.

The patient was prescribed medications at discharge, including Eliquis for Afib and metoprolol tartrate for hypertension. He was also advised to undergo evaluation for surgical or transcatheter intervention for severe aortic stenosis, continue hemodialysis three times a week, and consider stopping metoprolol tartrate due to bradycardia.

Overall, the patient's hospital course was marked by a syncopal episode likely due to a vagal episode in the setting of severe aortic stenosis, and he was discharged with recommendations for further evaluation and treatment. ||endoftext||
